importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Launch date of the National Education Equity Lab, which later became the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON).
Year in which 60% of Advanced Placement exams taken by low-income students scored too low for college credit, highlighting a systemic gap in college readiness.
Year when NEON reported an annual revenue of $7.5 million and continued scaling operations across Title I schools.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: NEON's goal to serve 1 million Title I high school students in the U.S. within a decade, aiming to surpass the number of low-income students taking Advanced Placement tests.

keyTakeAways: Education is framed as a civil rights issue due to systemic inequities in access to college-prep opportunities for low-income students.
NEON bridges the gap between elite universities and under-resourced schools by delivering college-level courses directly into high schools.
Students from low-income backgrounds, especially in rural and urban Title I schools, historically face a 'college-readiness' gap despite being talented and hard-working.
A 2017 Raj Chetty analysis revealed that top-tier colleges are the least socioeconomically diverse, indicating a structural barrier in access.
NEON’s model includes Zoom-based professor-student connections, teacher training, and college mentorship to build student confidence and college navigation skills.
NEON has delivered 60 college credit-bearing courses from 17 universities to over 40,000 students in 33 states with 80% pass rates.
The program is currently in every Title I school in Jackson, Mississippi, and 120 in New York City.
Support comes from the Carnegie Corporation, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, NBA, Apollo, Morgan Stanley, and individual donors like Henry McCance.
A study by Robert Balfanz found NEON students are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in college compared to peers.
NEON has faced challenges such as time investment from school leaders and scalability, but is growing rapidly with 35+ new districts expressing interest.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article chronicles the work of Leslie Cornfeld, a former federal civil rights prosecutor and education advisor, who launched the National Education Equity Lab in 2019 to address systemic inequities in college access for low-income students. Drawing on research showing elite universities are the least diverse in socioeconomic terms, Cornfeld developed the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON), which delivers college-level courses — such as Harvard’s poetry class — directly into Title I high schools. The model includes teacher training, student mentorship, and college preparation support. NEON has expanded to serve over 40,000 students across 33 states, with 80% pass rates and strong post-graduation outcomes: NEON students are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in them. Supported by the Carnegie Corporation, Gates Foundation, and others, and backed by individual donors like Henry McCance, NEON aims to serve 1 million students in Title I schools within a decade. The article positions education as a civil rights issue and contrasts NEON’s success with failed large-scale interventions like the Gates Foundation's Small Schools Initiative or Mark Zuckerberg’s Newark investment, emphasizing that smaller, evidence-based models can be more effective.
title: How a College-Level Course Network Is Closing the Gap for Low-Income Students
